data.text:
Dear Liz,

If youâ€™re anything like me, you remember seeing the ads for Winterâ€™s Tale and thinking, â€œSo, Colin Farrell is in love with that girl from Downton Abbey, but then he gets reincarnated in modern day New York? Or something?â€ The ads certainly suggested romance, and then some vaguely supernatural buggery-boo, but mostly they made no damn sense, and the film only grossed $30 million worldwide on a $60 million budget.

Why were the ads so cagey? This is a romance that opened on Valentineâ€™s Day â€” why not give us some indication of why Farrell winds up in present day New York, or what Russell Crowe is doing in the movie at all? Could it be that the studio simply wanted to indicate sweeping romance while hiding the fact that this movie is BUGFUCK INSANE??? Liz, this film is so crazy that I started taking notes about 1/3 of the way through because I knew I had to tell you about it. And now I will. [Oh, thank god. â€“Liz]

We open in 1895 New York, where Matt Bomer, who I very recently saw getting brutally stabbed to death on American Horror Story: Freak Show, is being denied admittance to the United States because he and his wife have consumption. Reasonable! But Bomer and wife reeeeally want their infant son to be let into America. Fortunately, Bomer spots a large model ship, plops his baby inside, and scoots it towards the shore. Good thing that model ship was actually seaworthy! That this plan is successful is the least crazy thing about this movie. [Oh, my god. â€“Liz]

Cut to 1916. The baby has become grown-ass man Colin Farrell, and heâ€™s being pursued by Russell Crowe and his army of bowler-sporting thugs. Turns out Farrellâ€™s a thief and Crowe was his mentor, his Fagin to Farrellâ€™s Artful Dodger, if you will. Croweâ€™s gang has Farrell cornered, when suddenly a white horse appears out of nowhere and jumps a 15-foot-high fence with Farrell astride him. OH COOL, MAGIC HORSE. Always useful to have one of those! (Seriously, though, Farrellâ€™s ass would be dead 100 times over in this movie if not for this magic horse.) The horse, it turns out, is a protective spirit, known as â€œThe White Dog of the East.â€ So why isnâ€™t it a dog? Well, weâ€™re told, sometimes it appears a horse. Sure, man. Look, letâ€™s just get on with this.

Ostensibly, Crowe is pursuing Farrell because Farrell tried to quit the bowler hat gang, but thereâ€™s another reason. Turns out Farrell has a â€œmiracleâ€ inside him that Crowe would like to prevent from occurring. Whatâ€™s that? Why would a New York gangster care about miracles? Oh, itâ€™s because Russell Croweâ€™s not just a gangster, heâ€™s a literal DEMON FROM HELL WHO WALKS NEW YORK CRUSHING MIRACLES AND TURNING MENâ€™S SOULS TO EVIL. This little bombshell is dropped when Crowe goes to a restaurant and orders an endangered owl off-menu. The waiter tell him they donâ€™t serve owl, so Crowe flashes a demon face, bashes the waiterâ€™s brains in, and then draws a pretty picture with his blood. TOTALLY NORMAL ROMANCE MOVIE STUFF. [:( ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ ğŸ˜¦ â€“Liz] The blood picture portrays the back of a red-headed woman, which leads Crowe to believe that Farrell will be performing his miracle on said woman. Solid demon detective work.

I should also mention that Crowe is doing an Irish accent for this role. It is a terrible accent. Just godawful. Russell Crowe must have some serious balls to have gone to set every day and do such a terrible accent right to Colin Farrellâ€™s face.

Anyway, Farrell understandably wants to leave town, what with DEMON HORDES pursuing him, but the horse/dog convinces him to do one last robbery. YOU HEARD ME. (I guess this makes the horse the same horse from Over The Garden Wall. Liz, you should watch Over the Garden Wall so you can get that reference.) [WILL DO. â€“Liz] Inside said house he finds the actress who plays the youngest daughter on Downton Abbey, whose name is Jessica Brown Findlay but who I will simply refer to as Downton. [As well you should. â€“Liz]

Downton is dying of consumption, but not the kind of consumption known to medical science. No, itâ€™s a kind of consumption where she never coughs or seems to feel any pain or distress, but instead sheâ€™s just really warm all the time. Like, if she goes outside barefoot, snow melts under her feet. So itâ€™s not consumption so much as very gradual human combustion. Anyway, Farrell and Downton fall in love basically instantly, because itâ€™s that kind of movie.

Eventually Croweâ€™s forces show up to Downtonâ€™s mansion. How did they know which woman to target? Because one of Croweâ€™s guys noticed she had red hair, like Croweâ€™s blood painting. He didnâ€™t see her with Colin Farrell or anything, he just thought â€œI know where a red-haired girl lives,â€ and Team Evil went all in. Apparently there is only one red-haired girl in all of New York. Either that or demons are dumb as rocks but exceedingly lucky. Farrell shows up on his magic horse to save her, but things look bad until the horse runs over a cliff, sprouts some GOSSAMER WINGS OF LIGHT, and gently delivers them to the ground below.

Turns out the horse isnâ€™t just a horse, itâ€™s also a freaking PEGASUS. Which, I think youâ€™ll agree, makes it EVEN LESS OF A DOG. On the animal scale it goes dog, horse, pegasus. As you can see, pegasus is further away than dog. Why is it never a dog? Wouldnâ€™t it be great if it was sometimes a dog? What would pull heartstrings more than a cute-ass dog THAT CAN CHANGE TO A PEGASUS AT WILL. Sorry, Iâ€™ll stop fantasy booking this movie. [Iâ€¦ I just canâ€™t. PEGASUS DOG HORSE. â€“Liz]

Farrell and Downton escape across the lake, and Crowe canâ€™t pursue them because he is confined to the five boroughs due to some old demon dispute. Handy! Fortunately, Downtonâ€™s family has a summer home in the area where they can lay low. Itâ€™s here where Farrell meets Downtonâ€™s dad, played by William Hurt, and has the CRAZIEST CONVERSATION IMAGINABLE. Here it is:

(Note: some words are spelled phonetically.)

HURT: Weâ€™ll have wine tonight. Will claret be all right with you?

FARRELL: Anything. But.. donâ€™t you pronounce it clar-ay?

HURT: No. Claret. We pronounce the â€˜tâ€™. Just as in â€˜fillette.â€™

FARRELL: â€˜Fillette?â€™ I always thought it was â€˜filet.â€™

HURT: No, itâ€™s â€˜fillette,â€™ just as in â€˜wallet.â€™ You donâ€™t pronounce it â€˜wall-ayâ€™ do you? You say â€˜wallet.â€™

FARRELL: I see.

(long, awkward pause)

WHAT IS HAPPENING I FEEL LIKE Iâ€™M LOSING MY MIND. [Also, wait, itâ€™s NOT â€˜filetâ€™ without the T? How class-less I am. â€“Liz] Anyway, Farrell also meets Downtonâ€™s little sister Willa, who shows Farrell the houseâ€™s Princess Bed. Willa insists that if Farrell kisses Downton in the Princess Bed, she wonâ€™t die. Iâ€™m inclined to believe her, since at this point I will believe literally anything these characters say.

Meanwhile, Crowe goes to see â€œThe Judgeâ€ to see if he can get his demonic limitations lifted. Turns out The Judge is Lucifer, you know, the ACTUAL CHRISTIAN DEVIL. In a wonderful twist, Lucifer is played by WILL SMITH, the ne plus ultra of stunt casting. Like seriously, holy cow. Lucifer is introduced lounging on a dingy mattress, reading A Brief History of Time, a book that will not be written for like 80 years. Itâ€™s PRETTY GREAT. [HOLY SHIT. â€“LIZ]

Long story short, Croweâ€™s demon human resources request is denied, so Crowe goes over Luciferâ€™s head and asks some other demon to poison Downton for him. The poisoner is played by Finn Whitrock, which I only bring up because heâ€™s the guy that stabbed Matt Bomer to death on American Horror Story! Small world! Small, murderous world.

Finn Whitlock (a fun name to say!) successfully poisons Downton at a ball, and when they get home, she and Farrell have sex. As they bask in the afterglow, Downton is basically like, â€œWell, that was nice. Gotta go!â€ and dies right in front Farrell. It is HYSTERICAL. Itâ€™s like he killed her with his dick. This gives me my much longed-for excuse to link to that comic where Spider-Man killed Mary Jane with his radioactive semen. AT LAST. [I know what this moment means to you, Jeff, and Iâ€™m just honored to be a part of it. â€“Liz]

Farrell races Downton down to the Princess Bed, kisses her corpse, and NOTHING HAPPENS, so what the hell kind of magical movie is this, anyway?!? That little girl straight-up lied to you, Colin Farrell! OR DID SHE?!

Farrell, despondent, returns to New York, only to be confronted by Russell Crowe. Farrell instructs his horse to fly away, which it does, looking exactly like the old TriStar Pictures intro in the process. Then Crowe proceeds to beat up Farrell USING ONLY HIS HEAD, which I admit is pretty bad-ass. Farrell falls in the water, then washes up on shore with AMNESIA. Oh, and he also came down with a strong case of IMMORTALITY, because skyscrapers fade in on the skyline and now weâ€™re in 2014 and Farrell is drawing chalk art of Russell Croweâ€™s Downton portrait. 100 years does nothing for his memory, however. Keeping Farrell alive 100 years really seems like Godâ€™s cheating in this Good vs Evil confrontation, but I guess Satan does have more manpower.

One day, Farrell meets Jennifer Connelly and her cancer-ridden daughter, who jog his memory enough to head back to Union Station and find some of his old shit. Unfortunately, regaining some of his memory sets off Russell Croweâ€™s Farrell-Sense, and he begins his hunt anew. Oh, Russell Crowe is still alive, too, but you probably figured that out, since heâ€™s a hell demon and everything. â€œWe may have killed the wrong redhead,â€ Crowe muses. It took Russell Crowe 100 years to realize there is more than one redhead on planet Earth.

Jennifer Connelly and Farrell become fast friends, and Connelly takes him to her job at the New York Times. Guess whoâ€™s her editor there? If you guessed â€˜Downtonâ€™s 100-plus-year-old sister,â€ then congrats on rolling with this movieâ€™s punches. [Like, identical twin sister? Eh, Iâ€™m sure. â€“Liz] It turns out that Farrell wasnâ€™t meant to miracle Downton, she was meant to miracle him, making him love her so much that he couldnâ€™t die. Thatâ€™s less of a miracle and more of an ironic punishment, but nobody said God was nice.

Crowe meanwhile, knows that killing an immortal guy will probably be difficult, so he checks in with Lucifer again. â€œI want him turned into snow!â€ he demands. Sure, man. Turns out that in order to kill Immortal Farrell, Russell Crowe has to put his own immortality on the line in their fight to the finish. Lucifer has seen movies before and tries to talk him out of it, but Crowe is too headstrong. Man, Lucifer was just trying to do you a solid, Russell Crowe! Why is Lucifer being so nice? â€œYou get used to people,â€ he admits, which is probably the nicest thing Satan is capable of saying. â€œIâ€™ve grown accustomed to your face!â€ my wife chimes in. So Crowe becomes mortal for his shot at Farrell. [Itâ€™s important to mention at this moment that I just added the â€œAkiva Goldsman is the worstâ€ tag to this post, because HE IS THE WORST. â€“Liz]

Farrell has dinner at Jennifer Connelyâ€™s place, and her adorable daughter gets a seizure. As sheâ€™s lying down, Farrell notices the daughter in the exact same pose as Croweâ€™s redhead portrait (with a red headscarf in place of red hair) and is like, â€œOH SHIT YOUâ€™RE MY ACTUAL JAM.â€ But then it turns out the daughter does have red hair, itâ€™s just that itâ€™s super short because of the chemo sheâ€™s been getting for her cancer? So the red hair in the vision was a scarf but the girl has red hair anyway, I guess because God works in dumb and mysterious ways. Anyway, on learning the daughter has cancer, Farellâ€™s like OH PS I KNOW ABOUT PRINCESS BEDS. Crowe shows up, and everyone runs to the roof to find THE MAGIC WHITE HORSE AW YISS. They fly the hell away to Downtonâ€™s old summer home because shit yeah, magic horse.

Team Evil shows up at the frozen lake anyway, since being mortal means Crowe no longer has any jurisdiction issues. â€œI suppose you know what to do, Horse,â€ says Farrell. [HE. DOES NOT. WAIT. OH, MY HUGH JACKMAN, I GUESS. HE DOES. â€“Liz] The horse takes off, smashes back down on the ice, and dooms all of Croweâ€™s men to a watery grave. The horse is BAD ASS. They should have called this movie Badass Pegasus Who Is Also A Dog Maybe.

This leaves Farrell and Crowe free to have a good olâ€™ fashioned fist fight. In my dream universe, Farrell and Crowe shared a gentlemanâ€™s agreement to hit each other for real, like they were UK wrestlers. Anyway, Crowe kicks Farrellâ€™s ass until some starlight gleams off the ice, distracting Crowe long enough for Farrell to STAB HIM IN THE NECK. As heâ€™s struggling with Crowe, holding a blade in his throat, Farrell throws a quick â€œThanks, stars!â€ smile to the heavens. â€œThank you, stars, for allowing me to kill this man via neck stabs. Surely heaven approveth of such an act.â€ Russell Crowe dies and turns to snow, just like how he wanted Farrell to die. Poetic justice? WHO CAN SAY.

Connellyâ€™s daughter chooses this exact moment to die of cancer, but Farrell gets her to the Princess Bed and she wakes up again. MIRACLE MANAGED. His miracle performed, Farrell jumps on his dog horse and shoots up into the heavens and become a star or some nonsense. So, in short, the God of Winterâ€™s Tale is one who will keep a guy alive for a century to save one girl with cancer, but canâ€™t be arsed to do anything about 9/11. Iâ€™m not theologian, but thatâ€™s pretty weird.
